subject: Counting assertions
msgSnippet: ... Mike makes an excellent point here. It is critical to ensure that your tests do something interesting, otherwise the numbers simply give you false
messageBody:
>"90 tests, 405 assertions" doesn't tell me much, however seeing something
>like "90 tests, 0 assertions" should raise a red flag in anyone's eyes.
>This
>sort of thing does happen and needs to be highlighted.

Mike makes an excellent point here. It is critical to ensure that your tests
do something interesting, otherwise the numbers simply give you false
security.

Certainly, at some point, as a developer, you have to think. Test-first
programming merely makes that thinking more effective, by concentrating on
coding the expected behavior of a class, then worrying about the details of
how to make the class beahve that way. If you write tests without thinking,
you're doomed, whether JUnit counts assertions or not.

If you want to count assertions, then be my guest. TestCase extends Assert,
so nothing stops you from creating class MyTestCase that extends TestCase
and overrides assertTrue() to do the counting. It does not need to be in the
framework or even a standard extension.

You could also use something like JesTer, which changes your code and
expects tests to fail. It can either identify code not tested (so either
test it or remove it) or pointless tests (so either fix it or remove it).

Do whatever makes sense for you, but don't get bogged down in counting
assertions for the sake of counting assertions. For the most part, people on
this list have insisted that the number, on its own, is largely meaningless.
Mike has pointed out a situation in which it has great meaning. I hope we
all read that and thought about it.

Simply: do what makes sense. Think. Share your ideas. Listen to
alternatives. Don't be so quick to change JUnit, though -- it didn't develop
overnight, you know. :)

JBR.
